title: 109_s3512
content: OFFSET OF STATE JUDICIAL DEBTS AGAINST INCOME TAX REFUND. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow the offset of past-due State judicial debts against income tax refunds. Upon notice from a State judicial branch, the Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount owed in State judicial debt. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting of past-due State judicial debts against income tax refunds. If an overpayment is reduced to satisfy a State judicial debt, the taxpayer must be notified. Offset is permitted only against residents of the state. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting of past-due State judicial debts against income tax refunds for residents of the state seeking offset. Overpayments are reduced after liabilities for internal revenue tax and past-due support are addressed. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting of past-due State judicial debts against income tax refunds for residents of the state. Overpayments are reduced after addressing liabilities for internal revenue tax, past-due support, and State income tax obligations. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies or the State judicial branch, any overpayment will be applied against those debts. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting of past-due State judicial debts against income tax refunds for residents of the state. Overpayments are reduced after addressing liabilities for internal revenue tax, past-due support, and State income tax obligations. Any overpayment by a person will be applied against debts in the order they accrued, with rules similar to subsection (e)(4) applying. Past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt refers to debts resulting from judgments or sentences in criminal or traffic cases by a court of competent jurisdiction in the state. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting of past-due State judicial debts against income tax refunds for residents of the state. State judicial debt includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to victims of crime. The Secretary will issue regulations for submitting notices of past-due debts. State judicial branches and State agencies must submit notices of past-due State judicial debts, including necessary information. Regulations will specify types of debts eligible for reduction and may require a fee for the reduction procedure. Any fees paid will reimburse the Secretary for applying the procedure. If an erroneous payment is made to a State, the Secretary will notify the State judicial branch or agency. An erroneous payment made to a State judicial branch or agency must be promptly repaid to the Secretary. Section 6103(l)(10) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include disclosure of information for reduction requests. Section 6402(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is subject to conforming amendments. Section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include subsection (f) for reducing overpayments related to State judicial debts and future federal tax liabilities. Section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include subsections (e) and (f) for reducing overpayments related to State judicial debts and future federal tax liabilities. The amendments made by this Act apply to refunds for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006.
